articles.headline: Justices Scrutinize Adviser Pay
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court is likely to announce a new standard for evaluating claims of excessive compensation of fund advisers.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court is likely to announce a new standard for evaluating claims of excessive compensation of fund advisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday appeared reluctant to allow judges to take on a major role in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers. But some justices nonetheless suggested that pay arrangements could be so outsized that the courts may have to step in.

articles.headline: Gore’s Dual Role: Advocate and Investor
articles.snippet: Al Gore says he is putting his money where his mouth is by investing in green technology, but critics say he’s profiteering.
articles.abstract: Al Gore says he is putting his money where his mouth is by investing in green technology, but critics say he’s profiteering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Al Gore thought he had spotted a winner last year when a small California firm sought financing for an energy-saving technology from the venture capital firm where Mr. Gore is a partner.

articles.headline: States Are Pondering Fraud Suits Against Banks
articles.snippet: Unable to do much about runaway foreclosures, the states’ top lawyers are thinking of suing banks for fraudulently marketing mortgages.
articles.abstract: Unable to do much about runaway foreclosures, the states’ top lawyers are thinking of suing banks for fraudulently marketing mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  Newly empowered by the Supreme Court, the attorneys general of several states hit hard by the housing collapse are exploring consumer fraud suits against major mortgage lenders.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and John Collins Rudolf

articles.headline: Lack of Paid Sick Days May Worsen Flu Pandemic
articles.snippet: About 40 percent of private-sector workers do not receive paid sick days, and many cannot afford to miss work.
articles.abstract: About 40 percent of private-sector workers do not receive paid sick days, and many cannot afford to miss work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Public health experts worried about the spread of the H1N1 flu are raising concerns that workers who deal with the public, like waiters and child care employees, are jeopardizing others by reporting to work sick because they do not get paid for days they miss for illness.

articles.headline: A Free Credit Score Followed by a Monthly Bill
articles.snippet: The government is trying to counter what it says are ads that trick consumers into paying for credit monitoring.
articles.abstract: The government is trying to counter what it says are ads that trick consumers into paying for credit monitoring.
articles.lead_paragraph: On television it’s hard to miss the wildly popular band of slackers singing ruefully from a shabby apartment or while waiting tables in pirate regalia. The ruined credit that led to their financial misfortune might have been sparkling if only they’d tracked their status on freecreditreport.com.
